messages.content: Syntax is a podcast about web development. Available at https://Syntax.fm
This episode is #603 entitled Can Vanilla CSS Replace Sass Yet?

Summarize the provided podcast transcript into very succinct bullet points, each containing just a few words. The bullet points should correspond to different sections or topics discussed in the podcast. Include any opinions the hosts have.

Remember, the key here is to read through the transcript carefully, identify the main points or topics, and then condense each one into a very brief, clear statement. It's also important to include timestamps if they're provided in the transcript, as they can help give a sense of the flow and structure of the podcast.

Additionally, Please create the following for this podcast episode:

1. 1-2 sentence description about what is covered in the podcast. This should be a short, catchy, and interesting description. It should provoke the listener to stop what they are doing and listen to the podcast.
1. 6-7 tweets for this podcast episode. These tweets should be short, catchy, and interesting. They should provoke the twitter user to respond an join in the conversation. Don't use any hash tags or emojis.
2. 6-7 tweets about this podcast that can be tweeted by listeners of the show. Some examples are "This is a fantastic episode about ___", or "I really enjoyed the part about ____"
3. 3-4 hashtags that categorize the episode. these will be used as topic tags on the website.
4. A summary of the podcast into a title. It should be catchy, slightly click-baity, and make the listener want to stop what they are doing and watch it.
5. Keep track of any links or websites mentioned in the podcast. These will be used as links on the website. If you can't find the link, provide only the name of the website.
6. tally the time each speaker speaks. This will be used to create a pie chart of who speaks the most.
7. For each speaker and topic, report sentiment analysis for positive, neutral, negative amd uncertain
8. Provide a MidJourney prompt to create artwork for the podcast

You may exclude transcripts from the Announcer and ad-reads from sponsors, unless the sponsor is Sentry.

Return each of these things in JSON format that looks like this:

{
  "title": "...",
  description: "...",
  "summary": [{time: '02:33', text: "..."}],
  "tweets: ["..."],
  "listener_tweets": ["..."],
  topics: ["...", "..."],
  links: [{ name: 'Name of link', url: 'https://example.com"}, "..."],
  speaker_times: [{name: 'Wes Bos', time: '02:33'}, "..."],
  sentiment_analysis: [{ topic: 'JavaScript', speaker: 'Wes Bos', sentiment: 'positive'}, ...],

}

00:01 Announcer:
Welcome to Syntax, the podcast featuring the tastiest web development treats with Scott Zelensky and West Boss. Strap in and get ready!

00:11 Wes Bos:
Welcome to Syntax, the tastiest web development podcast. Today we ask: Can Vanilla CSS replace all SAS features? We discuss nesting in CSS and whether it makes sense to switch from SAS or start a new project using Vanilla CSS. We'll review each SAS feature and give it a replaceable thumbs up, plausible, or no. It's like a mythbusters episode for web development. How are you doing today, Scott?

01:01 Scott Tolinski:
I'm good, man. Beautiful weather here. I've been in the yard, picking up leaves. Feels awesome! Had a great Easter Sunday. How was yours? Oh, pretty good, actually.

01:22 Wes Bos:
My sister visited for Easter and we enjoyed a big ham. The kids loved it, so it was a great Easter. They're still home today for Easter Monday, which I don't remember getting two days off for. I've never heard of Easter Monday before.

01:41 Scott Tolinski:
I thought, is that a thing? I asked Courtney when Easter is and she gave me a look like, come on, man. It's tomorrow. I'm not the best at remembering that stuff. We did a neighborhood kids' egg hunt and it was great. The family hosting did an amazing job. There were about 50 kids and no meltdowns. All the kids left happy. They were impressive hosts, even providing something for adults too. It was a nice Easter weekend. We did egg stuff, and my daughter loves bunnies, so she went crazy with all the bunny things. It's been a very bunny weekend for us.

02:53 Wes Bos:
Our backyard is bunny central, and our kids love watching them hop around. We also have many falcons in the neighborhood that often perch on light posts and swoop down to grab prey. The other day, we spotted half a bunny on the ground and had to explain to the kids that falcons enjoy eating bunnies.

03:20 Scott Tolinski:
I found a week-old bunny carcass in our front yard, which was the one we'd always see. I had to remove it before my daughter saw it. Despite having no falcons, we surprisingly have many bald eagles in Denver. I never used to see them, but now they appear in parks and on Reddit photos.

03:52 Wes Bos:
Yeah, we have a large banner in Hamilton featuring an eagle, signifying their return after 40 years. Their numbers have increased, which is cool. I'm not a patriotic American, but I appreciate a cool bird.

04:13 Scott Tolinski:
These cool birds are impressive, standing tall like people. Alright, let's dive in.

04:20 Wes Bos:
We'll examine SAS features, determining if they're replaceable and discuss alternatives. This isn't against compiling CSS, as you'll still need tools like post CSS for optimization, nor is it an anti-SAS argument. With jQuery, web standards evolved and it became less needed. Similarly, as CSS gains more features, we may not need SAS anymore.

05:25 Scott Tolinski:
Before being labeled a CSS Purist like that YouTuber, I want to clarify that my career started with SaaS tutorials and Compass tutorials. I've been a huge SaaS fan for a long time. However, if I say anything pro-browser-based CSS, it's not because I'm anti-SaaS. I still love SaaS, but we might not need it as much for certain tasks. Similar to how we view jQuery, some tasks might be better suited to different approaches. So, let's dive into that.

06:06 Wes Bos:
Want to discuss post CSS first? It's a bundler transformer for CSS, allowing plugins like auto-prefixer to add vendor prefixes based on browser support. Surprisingly, some things still need prefixes, like CSS gradient requiring -webkit-mask. Oddly, Chrome hasn't "un-prefixed" it, though Firefox and others support regular mask. Post CSS works for older browsers too.

07:46 Scott Tolinski:
Yeah, vendor prefixing for CSS was a thing during the early development career when CSS 3 dropped with new features and browser prefixes. It led to the need for tools like SaaS, but as the web evolved, we started thinking less about prefixes, and people started using tools like post CSS to compile CSS and handle browser support.

Post CSS, like Babbel, targets specific browser versions for support and has a plugin ecosystem for adding specific CSS features, supporting prefixes, removing unused code, and more. Even without using Sassy CSS or other tools, post CSS is used in almost every project to provide baseline coverage.

09:53 Wes Bos:
Firstly, variables are well supported in all browsers. Using regular CSS variables is better due to their live updates in the client. Though the syntax is funky, it's easy to get used to. Changing a variable causes updates to ripple throughout the entire application.

10:30 Scott Tolinski:
You can scope specific selectors with variables, which we'll discuss more with mixins. Scoping is essential as we see a shift towards scope CSS in frameworks, CSS and JS frameworks, and web components. CSS variables provide an interface to update these elements in a more controlled manner, making it easier to override and augment properties.

Variables are crucial for dealing with dark mode, light mode, themes, and sizes. They also have default values, allowing for easy customization and overriding. CSS variables are among the greatest improvements in CSS, differing from Sass variables that only exist at compile time and are limited for dynamic situations.

12:19 Wes Bos:
That's a quick variable find and replace, working better than expected. I posted about discussing colors soon and showed how changing one variable updates the rest. Many said they'd prefer pre-compiling to avoid using users' resources and CPU for opacity calculations. However, I can get any color with this method. If I pre-calculated 20 colors and 8 variations each, that's 160 color combinations. So, what's better: calculating in ESLint or shipping extra CSS for all situations?

13:37 Scott Tolinski:
Not certain, but show me the inflow. Shameful, wasteful use of people's network, not considering usage, West. Can't win.

13:53 Wes Bos:
Next, we have CSS nesting, which just dropped and is the main reason people use SAS. It makes it easier to write a selector and nest another inside it, like selecting links or a specific class within a menu. Nesting can cause issues if overdone, but it's convenient. Now available in Safari Technology Preview, it can be compiled with post CSS to unnested CSS, allowing its use in every browser today.

14:55 Scott Tolinski:
Yes, I really like that nesting has finally found its sweet spot in CSS. Initially, nesting resulted in CSS being indented too deep, and there was a whole "nesting is harmful" movement. However, now nesting is useful for scoping components and avoiding repetition of class names or property selectors, providing a nice interface.

When Sass introduced nesting, it greatly improved CSS writing, as you didn't have to think about selector nesting as much. Now we have this in-browser, and although some criticize the syntax compared to Sass's, it still brings improvements. In Sass, you just use an ampersand to represent the parent for pseudo selectors. With the new CSS nesting, you almost always have to indicate the parent, but that's due to CSS parsing.

So, have there been updates to the CSS parser?

17:01 Wes Bos:
The approved and released version is very close to SaaS, allowing you to nest a selector inside the parent without needing an ampersand. The ampersand is only necessary when doing element selectors. For instance, with a .wrapper and .sidebar, you can just select .sidebar; but for a div or span, use the & div. Leivaroo has a good GitHub thread explaining that this is related to positive look-ahead regular expressions, and they're exploring removing this requirement in future versions. Despite this minor inconvenience, using an ampersand isn't a big deal, and the current CSS nesting feels and looks great. It seems like it was just a few months ago when SCSS-style nesting wasn't yet figured out.

18:42 Scott Tolinski:
The exciting part is that now we have native media query nesting in CSS, a killer feature for many users. You can simply use @media inside a selector and write your CSS within. This has always been a huge aspect of CSS nesting usage, so it was vital for any nesting API that hit browsers to include media queries. Thanks to Adam Argyle's blog post on developers.chrome.com, you can find many practical examples that demonstrate the new nesting rules and syntax. The post covers various use cases and does a great job showing the before and after comparisons.

19:49 Wes Bos:
A cool feature in SaaS is nesting container queries within nested containers. This allows for easy application without naming the container. Another lesser-known feature is "breaking out of the selector," which can be done using the ampersand at the end of a selector; this works in native CSS as well.

SaaS recently released a blog post about adding native CSS nesting to SaaS. The proposed idea is to include regular CSS in a SaaS file, but it won't compile - this limits the use of SaaS variables. Although not an ideal solution, it's a step forward. Users would still need to post CSS compile for older browser support.

21:54 Scott Tolinski:
It's iffy, but you might wonder why to use native nesting when CSS provides the same features. Well, you'd ship less code. While it may not matter much in terms of compression engines, you'll still save by shipping fewer things. When compiling a nested script, it has to inline duplicate selectors based on layers depth, which isn't insignificant, especially with is.

22:29 Wes Bos:
Like, the classic example is selecting h1-h6 in a card. Before, you'd compile with dot h1 dot H2H3like dot card space h1 comma dot card space h2. Yeah. Now we just use is.

22:54 Scott Tolinski:
Dot card colon includes h1-h6, and it might not make a huge difference in your code compilation. There should be some savings in efficiency, right? 

Colors in SASS are impressive, but not as dynamic as CSS variables. SASS allows you to compute colors from existing ones, which was a great feature. However, with different SASS APIs and hard-to-parse documentation, using SASS color functions has become frustrating. Currently not using SASS, the future of manipulating colors in the browser looks promising with new features like color mix, contrast, and relative colors. 

The downside to this is losing the semantic function names, which is something SASS does well.

24:43 Wes Bos:
Darkened Leitchen, dark, requires using relative color or color mix function. Built-in color functions depend on browser support, can't be compiled away, but could be polyfilled with JavaScript. You can pass one color, e.g., Freshbooks invoicing takes your brand color syntax (yellow) and calculates darker, lighter, and accent colors. Very cool.

25:23 Scott Tolinski:
Listen to color episodes for more on colors in upcoming features.

25:30 Wes Bos:
Oh, we forgot to determine if that was good, better, plausible, or replaceable for these options. Variables are replaceable, as is ESLint. Colors are plausible since they need to be compiled. You could use a post CSS plugin to compile at build time, providing the same outcome as SaaS but without live support for older browsers. You could also use support queries for compatibility.

In many cases, I prefer writing to the spec rather than using SaaS or a random post CSS plugin, as those might not adhere to the standard. I'll use the spec version and keep things static until browsers support it. For what I'll use, it's post CSS with the preset INV.

27:35 Wes Bos:
Nesting can be compiled to regular selectors, and Deno features aren't missed. I understand the container queries point. Other features can be compiled too. Arrow functions in JavaScript are compatible even with IE6. Features like symbols might be difficult to incorporate. Nesting, however, can be used today and just needs to be compiled.

28:21 Scott Tolinski:
the expanded selector, and I don't think you lose anything. When considering if it's fully replaceable without post CSS, well, it isn't. That's why I interjected. I believe you'll always use

28:37 Wes Bos:
PostCSS: Use preset ENV, specify supported browsers, and it decides whether to compile, transpile, polyfill features or ship directly to browsers, based on their support. No need to do so if all browsers support it.

29:00 Scott Tolinski:
Totally. Let's discuss looping, which isn't in CSS now but is in SaaS. With loops, you can increment numbers and use them for various properties, like math and color work. I remember using loops for things modern CSS can do, like nth child. Before, we'd loop to apply styles every third item, but now we have nth child for that. Even with layouts, we used loops for grid systems, floating and percentage widths. But now, we have grid and flexbox, so I wonder what we'd even use loops for in modern CSS today ‚Äì I don't have a good answer.

30:17 Wes Bos:
Yeah, in most cases, it's not needed with auto-fit, auto-fill, and advanced selectors. You can use a variable for different instances, like assigning different colors for CSS, HTML, JavaScript, and TypeScript. Write a selector with a variable, and pass it inline or as a style attribute. It'll be applied to every single one.

I faced an edge case recently where looping would be helpful. I was creating an HSL color picker and wanted to loop the rainbow with a gradient of every hue from 0 to 360. I tried using a linear gradient from HSL(0) to HSL(360) but got an unexpected color result.

To achieve this, I added a stop every 45 degrees. With such a large selector, CSS couldn't be used without a loop or math. I added 8 stops, each at a specific degree. This situation might arise in animations as well.

32:46 Scott Tolinski:
Yeah, whenever you need to automate something mathematical, there's a place for it. It's funny because I just

Yes. Alright.

Instead, I could have used a "background" variable and looped over it with React or Svelte when generating HTML. However, it's not in the same place, so I'll give this point to SAS while acknowledging that ESLint styles have their advantages as well.

33:55 Scott Tolinski:
You likely don't need most cases, so I want to tackle those. I understand your love for using JavaScript and CSS with ESLint or Svelte's property to define CSS variables as props. It's great using JavaScript and CSS together like this for me too.

Let's discuss Mixins or extends, which allow you to write one piece of CSS functionality that can be applied to multiple classes. Though it sounds like just a class, Mixins function more like functions as they can accept inputs, acting as small utilities without needing a separate class. However, this might lead to questions about reusable CSS and whether it's too repetitive.

I believe Mixins could be a useful feature in CSS, though I'm open to being convinced otherwise. It's not a necessity, but it has potential benefits.

35:33 Wes Bos:
I wasn't a fan of mixins, as it was difficult to locate their origin when compiled. Perhaps I wasn't great with Sass, but I preferred using variables. For example, with border radius and padding adjustments, you can pass a CSS variable and calculate based on that. I reviewed Sass documentation and asked GPT for 10 mixin examples, but couldn't find one that couldn't be replaced by adding a second class or passing a varying component through a variable.

36:35 Scott Tolinski:
Yeah, I'd love to go through my level up tutorials repo while we talk, checking the 2016 version to see what mixins I used then. I recall really liking them. It's interesting how things evolve, and how CSS variables have changed a lot. With the scoping for variables tied to a specific class, it reduces the need for mixins.

37:17 Wes Bos:
Mixins in general had a proposal in the CSS working group called "apply." It allowed setting a CSS variable with multiple properties. You'd define a variable, e.g., dash dash cool corners, followed by colon and curly brackets with different properties inside. The proposal introduced "at apply" to apply those properties to a selector. However, it was scrapped due to scoping and CSS variable issues. After reading a blog post explaining why it doesn't work, it's unlikely this feature will be implemented in native CSS. Instead, focus on alternative approaches to solve the problem. So, is that replaceable, plausible, or missing?

38:26 Scott Tolinski:
I I would go as far as saying it's missing,but Like I said, it's replaceable.

38:31 Wes Bos:
I mean,

I'll revisit if there's anything particular I wish to retain from mixins. Please, send us at pnpm XFM.

39:07 Wes Bos:
Tweet us your mixing codes and say, okay hot shot, let's see how you handle this. I have a unique edge case and I dislike when people say don't use that without knowing my app's use cases. I‚Äôd like to see a decent solution that isn't terrible with setting variables and looping JavaScript.

39:34 Scott Tolinski:
Yes. Yes, please.

39:36 Wes Bos:
Partials is next. Including CSS in separate files allows for better organization and importing. However, CSS imports can cause waterfalling, where multiple requests occur in sequence, slowing down your experience. This issue persists even with HTTP/2, as it's a browser-related problem.

Two solutions from Vercel are: 1) bundling CSS into a single file or loading only necessary bits on specific pages, and 2) using preload. For instance, Google Fonts provides a link rel=preload to preload font requests. This informs the browser to fetch the font early, avoiding delays when it's needed later.

41:18 Scott Tolinski:
tag in Google fonts does. This seems prime for a CSS glow up. The syntax is mostly what everyone uses in SaaS. It's just the functionality, right? How the browser handles import; if it changed from waterfall, would things break? I don't know enough. Am I

The issue with JavaScript modules is that the browser doesn't know what it needs until it downloads and parses the file. There was a proposal for the server to parse your CSS and TypeScript, walking the entire import tree, and then send all the required files in a single HTTP 2 request. However, this requires buy-in from the Vercel, which we don't have yet. Bundling is a solution, but requiring server buy-in for CSS doesn't seem right. There was a hinting header where you can hint to the browser about potential downloads, but it was scrapped.

Speaking of functions, they work great in SaaS, allowing you to pass values, perform operations, and return results. I often use functions in CSS and create my own in SaaS, but with JavaScript-based functions in CSS, we enter Deno and Houdini territory. Houdini aimed to bring JavaScript APIs to CSS, enabling us to write custom properties. However, Houdini's progress has stagnated; it is a thing but not really.
